DIV2.P: The Image Class is a system of tools and methods for providing web-based access to diverse image databases. The Image Class was created at the University of Michigan in the Digital Library Production Service. At the University of Michigan, the Image Class [ http://images.umdl.umich.edu ] provides broad access to a wide range of library, museum, archive, visual resources, and special collections. The Image Class is specifically geared for continuous tone images. Continuous tone images are image files commonly with a bit depth of 24 for color, and 8 for grayscale. The demands for capture of the features of the source materials dictate the bit depth of the image. For example, the complex features of a papyri and art images cannot be captured with bitonal methods, and are thus captured at a high bit-depth and high resolution. Strictly speaking, an image with a bit depth greater than 1 can be considered continous tone. Continous tone images usually come with associated bibliographic or descriptive information, as well as more complex administrative metadata. Currently, the associated descriptive information is the primary means of locating these images in the Image Class, but browsing mechanisms are also made available to users. Descriptive metadata also varies from minimal--e.g., only a title--to rich, with complex vocabularies for subject and theme analysis. Of special importance in the Image Class are methods for navigating high resolution images (e.g., pan and zoom) and methods for using images in a variety of contexts (e.g., comparing images or creating small collections for study).
The Image Class serves two main purposes.

OL.LI: Online access to continuous tone images (i.e., full color and grayscale)

DIV2.P: The Image Class provides advanced funtionality for access to continous tone images. Continous tone images are typically have 24 bits of color or 8 bits of gray values. Advanced functionality includes the abilty to view the entire image at a variety of resolutions, and panning and zooming.
The Image Class federates image databases at the point of access. Access minimally includes search and retrieval of descriptive text records and display of digital images associated with the record.

UL.LI: Text based search and retrieval of images
Searching across multiple collections simultaneously
Searching of each collection independently
Useful display functions and customizable interface layouts
Advanced image display functionality, including panning and zooming
Bookmarkable records and images
Minimal descriptive data requirements
Reasonable data submission process for database managers
Simple data transformation process for online deployment
Uses a single data model and shared middleware for all databases in the system
Storage of multiple image resolutions in a single file format
Assimilates data from practically any management system
Access restrictions at collection and image levels

DIV2.P: At the University of Michigan, the Image Class access system is administered by the Digital Library Production Service, Image Services. Image Services receives data (descriptive metadata and digital images) on a periodic basis from a variety of organizations on and off campus, and fully handles the process of putting the data online in a production level environment. Image Services has technical expertise and resources for providing reliable online access to image collections. This is not the only model for implementing the Image Class, but it is one that has worked.

The Image Class provides no functionality for creating and managing image databases. Database management is handled by separate systems under the control of the organizations that have provided collections. For example, the University of Michigan Museum of Art uses Embark as a database management system. The Museum provides public access through Image Services and the Image Class.
The following sources of data have influenced the process defining the Image Class. Other sources are possible.

UL.LI: Libraries: photograph collections, manuscripts, papyrus
Museums: art, archaeological
Visual Resources: slide libraries, slide vendors
Campus database access
Public database access
Cross collection searching; any combination of collections
Simple and Boolean searching
Results viewing as thumbnail, text, or slideshow
Display of complex image structures (Please scroll through entire page.)
Zooming and panning for image display; integrated into template scheme; no special client software needed
Flipping among pages/images associated with a record
Comparison of two images from two searches
Browsing, either by a canned query embedded in a link, or with a the "word wheel." (note that the word wheel is not currently an integral component of the Image Class)

DIV2.P: Campus image collections, such as those found in museums, libraries, and departments, are spread across campus, and managed independently and differently. Each collection is unique, from the nature of the images, to the cataloging methods, to the management system, and providing public access to catalogs and images requires an understanding of the similarities and disparities that exist. No amount of technology will fully resolve the differences among data, and only an appropriate and practical application of technology and the sharing of documentation methods, will make a broad service image access system work well to serve instructional and research needs. The Image Class federates collections at the point of access in order to best support the diversity of collections and management practices.

The Image Class supports descriptive text databases that are built of structured records and fields. Continuous tone image files are typically associated with the database, and referenced by filename data maintained in one of the fields. Within this basic structure there are many variations. Digital images are actually not a requirement, though if they are available, they must be continuos tone. The basic variations are as follows:

UL.LI: zero digital images per record
one digital image per record
multiple digital images per record

DIV2.P: A database may have any combination of the above. Once deployed in the Image Class, it is possible to represent each individually in a search results set, even though they are from a single record. When the record is viewed, links to all referenced images are displayed. For example, a search for "4110" in the Kelsey Amulet collection comes up with 2 results, both from one record.

It has been discovered through experience with multiple datasets from internal and external sources that data structures vary only slightly (as depicted in the table above), but that the content in the structures varies tremendously. As an example, compare the artist field in the Museum of Art database with the creator field in William Blake's Songs of Innocence and Experience.

The disparities are not much of a problem until searching across databases is attempted. It is a considerable achievement that the Image Class supports cross-collection searching, and that it does so without forcing low level normalization of the data. All database specific fields are available to the user for search and display when doing a collection specific search. In the cross-collection search all of the fields are available, but only through a common set of generalized field mappings (thought of as high level normalization). For example, a cross-collection search on a common field called "creator" searches the artist field of the Museum of Art database and the creator field of the Blake database.

The Image Class by default uses a basic version of Dublin Core [ http://purl.oclc.org/dc/ ]as the set of common fields for cross-collection searching. Any common set of fields may be used in addition to or in place of Dublin Core. It is easy to envision the situation where subsets of collections use core field sets that are suitable to their subject. For instance, databases from slide libraries might be drawn together with the VRA Core [ http://www.oberlin.edu/~art/vra/core.html ] (Visual Resources Association).

It is possible to represent complex image relationships in the Image Class. For example, a summary image with several additional images as detailed views. Or a matrix of images that together represent something larger. The Advanced Papyrological Information System makes good use of these features.

Continuos tone images serve clearly different purposes than bitonal images. Bitonal images are typically used for text page images and other high contrast imaging situations where gradations among the visual elements of the page are not essential to the intellectual value of the content represented. For example, in most cases the intellectual value of a typeset page from a book can be fully captured in a bitonal image. The purpose is met if the text is readable. A color photograph, however, will typically lose valuable information if the full range of tones is not captured in the digital image. Given this, continuos tone images and bitonal images, need vastly different functionality for viewing by users. Bitonal images generally need to be flipped like the pages of a book, and continuos tone images need to be evaluated in a glance for relevance or inspected at the greatest detail. The generalizations are obvious, and there are already situations in the Image Class where continuos tone images are flipped like the pages of a book. But, the Image Class specializes in serving the most popular uses of continuos tone images by providing pages of thumbnails for making sweeping relevance decisions, and powerful panning and zooming functionality for inspecting the finest details of an image.

Digital images are retrieved by the unique record identifiers of the text database, and never by filename. Filenames, moreso than record identifiers, have potential to change over time. The Image Class implementation strives to provide reliable, long term, access to specific records and images.

The flexibility of the Image Class to assimilate databases and that same time maintain unique characteristics of each is perhaps it's greatest strength. The advanced capabilities for viewing continuous tone images may be just as important. The Image Class successfully handles databases from a variety of domains including art, art history, architecture, archaeology, archives, and journals. The baseline requirement is only that there is some degree of item level description-- minimally a unique identifier.

The data structure and behaviors of the Image Class best serve the functional requirements of single images (e.g., photographs), and multiple images that provide multiple views of single objects (e.g., views of a sculpture). Multiple images from a bound manuscript or illustrated journal are also handled well, especially when a text-based counterpart exists (e.g., Harper's Weekly [ http://www.hti.umich.edu/h/harpersweekly/ ]). At this time the Image Class has basic functionality for page flipping, which is more often handled in a text system. If in the future a considerable amount of content emerges that requires both continuous tone images and book-like functionality, it may be sensible to establish a new class to better serve the homogeneity and distinctiveness of the content in the Image Class and in the spin-off class.

Digital video and audio also have potential to stretch the Image Class in unsuitable ways. The Image Class was actually designed with the notion that it might some day accommodate video and audio in the future. It is easy to envision using the Image Class as a starting place for these media types. It also seems likely that the time-based characteristics of video and audio would instantiate a new class based on the existing flexible fielded text searching with added time-based functionality. Consideration also needs to be given to the question of whether it is appropriate to search still images, video, and audio together. Similarly, methods of searching still images by visual characteristics are evolving and it may soon be desirable to complement the text searching with such features. This does not necessarily put a tension on the Image Class as it is, but might increase the likelihood of splitting away other media types.

DIV3.P: The Image Class relies on a single Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML) Document Type Definition (DTD) to represent all collections in the class. Typically each collection has descriptive text in a database of records and fields. The fielded data is exported from the database to a simple ASCII text format. The fielded data is then encoded with the SGML tags defined by the DTD giving it a clearly defined and parsable structure. The SGML is then indexed and made searchable on the Web by the Image Class middleware.

In the General Parameters section the variety of record to image relationships were described. The structure imposed by the Image Class DTD normalizes these relationships in order to optimize search and retrieval performance. Descriptive data is replicated within the SGML in order to create a 1 to 1 relationship between the descriptive data provided by the original text record and all of the image files associated with the record. The original hierarchical relationship (one record with many images) are maintained through additional tagging and structure that wraps the multiple images together in an itemized fashion. A more detailed breakdown, with examples, is available in the document Image Class DTD Description.

The outstanding strength of the Image Class DTD is the way that it encodes the full set of collection specific data categories while mapping the categories to a more general set of categories commonly applied to all collections of the Class. This topic is covered fully in the General Parameters section of this document.
The Image data in the Image Class is continous tone, most often meaning 24-bits of color or 8-bits of grayscale pixel data.
Thumbnail size images used in the display of search results are stored on the server as static JPEG (JFIF format with lossy JPEG compression) files. The GIF format is also supported.

The larger, display, version of an image may be stored on the server as a static JPEG (JFIF format with lossy JPEG compression) file in two resolutions (large and medium), or in a SID format (LizardTech's MrSID [ http://www.lizardtech.com ] format with lossy wavelet compression) file with multiple levels of resolution inherently available through the compression scheme. The SID format is a far superior option with compression ratios of 20 to 1 easily achieved with minimal image degradation and multiple resolutions by default. Since the SID format is not supported internally by web browsers, the Image Class middleware extracts image data from the SID format on the fly and delivers it to the browser in the JPEG format. MrSID allows the extraction of any portion of any predefined resolution level from an image, enabling panning, zooming, and cropping functionality in the user interface.

DIV2.P: The University of Michigan, Museum of Art, The Kelsey Museum of Archaeology's Registry Database, and William Blake's Songs of Innocence and Experience are resources implemented in the Image Class that represent well the depth and breadth of intended use.

The University of Michigan, Museum of Art
[ http://images.umdl.umich.edu/m/musart/ ]

A comprehensive and growing catalog of the Museum's holdings, the implementation of this database in the Image Class is the best all around example. There are over 12,000 text records, and over 10,000 digital images. Most records have one digital image, some records have multiple images, and a far smaller number do not yet have digital images. In the mid-1990's the Museum photographed and digitized the entire collection. At the same time they migrated their collection management database to the DCI Embark system. The Embark system provides good internal management functionality for curators, including the ability to view the digital images. Image Services provides public access to the collection via the Image Class. The digital images provided by the Museum are of very high quality and make good use of the advanced image viewing functionality of the Class. The Museum of Art data is updated about three times a year, but as often as monthly. Additionally, it is worth noting that the Museum restricts access outside of the University to some large versions of images due to copyright restrictions.

The Kelsey Museum of Archaeology's Registry Database
[ http://images.umdl.umich.edu/k/kelsey/ ]

The Kelsey manages a database of over 90,000 records that describes the physical artifacts held by the museum. Currently there are about 200 digital images associated with the database. The Kelsey uses FileMaker Pro, setup with a relational structure that includes several tables. Previous to providing public access through Image Services, the Kelsey provided restricted access to the database with FileMaker's database sharing capabilities on an under powered Macintosh. The database is now available to the world through the Image Class. The Kelsey database is updated in the Image Class quarterly. Recently 200 images were digitized by Image Services. The images are the primary images used by two UM courses, and are available in conjunction with the Kelseyt entity entity's Registry Database.

William Blake's Songs of Innocence and Experience
[ http://images.umdl.umich.edu/b/blake/ ]

Blake's Songs is an illustrated manuscript that is preferably accessed by searching the full text. The digital images are color, and of high enough quality to merit use of the Image Class advanced image viewing functionality. Blake's Songs, implemented as a "collection" in the Image Class, has only one bibliographic-like record with all of the manuscript's images associated with it. The record also has descriptive title's for each image, taken from the text of each page. It is valuable to have Blake's Songs in the Image Class so that users searching across collections have an opportunity to discover the illustrated manuscript pages along with works by Blake in other collections. Furthermore, the searchable text which is online on a separate machine in a separate system, has links to the images in the Image Class, and vice-versa. The links are handled by the DLPS ID Resolver, which is a simple mechanism for resolving a unique identifier into a URL. This interoperability provides the user with the best functions for viewing images and the best functions for retrieving text, and delegates functionality in an appropriate manner.
The decision process for inclusion of content in the Image Class is roughly based on the following:

UL.LI: Digital images are, or potentially would be in cases where digital images are not yet available, continuous tone (i.e., color or grayscale)
Descriptive text is structured in fields, such as in a database
The database describes, directly in the case of museums, or indirectly in the case of visual resources collections, images, objects, artifacts, or specimens, that contain visual information.
The campus and/or world community would benefit from access to the information.

DIV2.P: These are, at best, general guidelines for decision making based on the current state of the Image Class implementation at the University of Michigan. There is plenty of room to diversify the content, or deploy additional instantiations of the Class to serve another content area.
